1 Project Background
A prescription (R) is a written order by a physician or medical doctor to a pharmacist in the form of medication instructions for an individual patients You can’t get prescription medicines unless someone with authority prescribes them.
Usually, this means a written prescription from your doctor.
Dentists, optometrists, midwives and nurse practitioners may also be authorized to prescribe medicines for you.
It can also be defined as an order to take certain medications.
A prescription has legal implications; this means the prescriber must assume his responsibility for the clinical care ofthe patient.
Recently, the term “prescription” has known a wider usage being used for clinical assessments,

To be, or not to be,--that is the question:-- Whether ‘tis nobler in the mind to suffer
The slings and arrows of outrageous fortune
Or to take arms against a sea of troubles,
And by opposing end them?

--To die,--to sleep," No more; and by a sleep to say we end
The heartache, and the thousand natural shocks That flesh is heir to,--'tis a consummation
Devoutly to be wish'd.

To die,--to sleep;--
To sleep!

perchance to dream:--ay, there's the rub; For in that sleep of death what dreams M come, When we have shufﬂed off this mortal coil,
Must give us pause: there's the respect
That makes calamity of so long life;\
For who would bear the whips and seams of time, The oppressor's wrong, the proud man's contumely, The pangs of despis'd love, the law's delay,
The insolence of office, and the spurns
That patient merit of the unworthy takes,
When he himself might his quietus make
With a bare bodkin?
who would these fardels bear, To qrunt and sweat under a wearv life.

p.sent:
Reader (Read-Aloud) Accommodation
The use of a Reader may be provided for a student who has a documented reading disability that is two or more grade-levels below the student’s enrollment grade and that severely limits the student from decoding at any level of difﬁculty.

Criteria for a read-aloud accommodation: 0 Documented reading disability
0 Reading two or more grade-levels below current enrollment grade 0 Justiﬁcation (proof of success)
The deﬁcit should be addressed throughout the student’s IEP or 504 Plan, and the student should be working toward mastery of those deﬁcit skills.
The criteria for determining the use of a Reader shall not be solely dependent upon the student’s grade level performance or hjs/her cognitive ability.
(Education Specialist’s “Accessibility and Accommodations” PowerPoint, P. 5, top slide)

RACHEL
FRIDAY, JULY 5, 2013
MORNING
There is a pile of clothing on the side of the train tracks.
Light-blue cloth— a shirt, perhaps—jumbled up with something dirty white.
It’s probably rubbish, part of a load dumped into the scrubby little wood up the bank.
It could have been left behind by the en- gineers who work this part of the track, they’re here often enough.
Or it could be something else.

My mother used to tell me that I had an overac— tive imagination; Tom said that, too, I
9 of 28
can’t help it, I catch sight ofthese dis— carded scraps, a dirty T-shirt or a lonesome shoe, and all I can think of is the other shoe and the feet that ﬁt— ted into them.
The train jolts and scrapes and screeches back into motion, the little pile of clothes disappears from View and we trundle on towards London, moving at a briskjogger’s pace.
Some- one in the seat behind me gives a sigh of helpless irritation; the 8:04 slow train from Ashbury to Euston can test the patience of the most seasoned commuter.
The journey is supposed to take ﬁfty—four minutes, but it rarely does: this section of the track is an- cient, decrepit, beset with signalling problems and never—ending engineer— ing works.

Cedric himself lmew nothing whatever about it It had never been even mentioned to him.

He knew that his papa had been an Englishman, because his mamma had told him so; but then his papa had died when he was so little a boy that he could not remember very much about him, except that he was big, and had blue eyes and a long mustache, and that it was a splendid thing to be carried around the room on his shoulder.

How are students assessed?

0 Students will take three exams at the end of Year 11 0 We follow the OCR specification
- Sociology Basics
- Socialisation, Culture and Identity
- Applying Sociological research techniques
° No coursework means exam practice, homework, responding to feedback is essential!

° During Year 10 and 11 students will be assessed
formally through practice questions, in class tests and the mock papers (AfL)
° Data points will be based on these

What is Optical Character Recognition?

7 Optical Character Recognition or OCR is a system that provides a full alphanumeric recognition of printed or handwritten characters at electronic speed by simply scanning the form.
7 It is the mechanical or electronic conversion of scanned or photographed images of typewritten or printed text into machine—encoded/computer— readable text.
7 OCR is a field of research in pattern recognition, artificial intelligence and computer vision.

It is the electronic translation of handwritten, typewritten or printed text into machine translated images.

p.sent:
Bank OCR considerations
' Which algorithm did you chose?
' How readable are your test cases?
(Can you look at them and easily see which digits are being parsed?)
' How do you match digits?
(Are you usinglow level Ifs or high level patterns to match?)
' Functional or imperative?
(Do you use iteration or recursion?)
' What if the input changes?
What aboutthe style of digits, number of digits, ...)

Tms publication of the Works of Joan Knox, it is supposed, will extend to Five Volumes.
It was thought advisable to commence the series with his Histery of the Reformation in Scotland, as the work of greatest importance.
The next volume will thus contain the Third and Fourth Bookg which continue the History to the year 1564; at which period his historical labours my be considered to tenninete.
But the Fiﬁh Book, forming a. sequel to the History, and published under his name in 1644, will also be included.

His Letters and Misoellancuus Writings will be arranged in tho mbsequent volumes, as nearly as possible in chronolo- gical order; each portion being introduced by a separate notice, respecting the manuscript or printed copies from which they have been taken.
It may perhaps be expected that a Life of the Author ehould have been preﬁxed to this volume.
The Life of Knox1 by DH.
M‘lez, is however a work so universally known. and of so much historical value, as to supersede any attempt that might he made for a detailed bio-
What is OCR?
OCR also called Optical Character Recognition is a system that provides a full alphanumeric recognition of printed or handwritten characters at electronic speed by simply scanning the form.

This involves photo scanning of the text character-by-character, analysis of the scanned- in image, and then translation of the character image into character codes, such as ASCII, commonly used in data processing.
the reader better understand what they have read.

Text features provide information ‘
\ .

Authors include text features to help ‘
that may not be written in the text itself.
Text features can be found in textbooks, magazine articles, newspapers, reports, web pages, and other forms of nonfiction text.

p.sent: Certainly theology needs empirical facts and scientific theoretical insights The social scientists offer help.

Yet they do not accomplish what I must now attempt My main question is where and how the church must stand to be the witnssing church; that is, what must be the relation between the culture that is the church (and the larger Christian and biblical metaculture the church represents) and those cultums the dmxch indwells, evangelizes, serves?
Answering will require all the resources that Christian theology can bring to bear, and not a little help from such as Berger and Bellah as well.
Almady they have showed us, willymilly, that theology is required for the task: they make such ample (and often skillful) use of it, themselves!

INTRODUCTION
> Optical character recognition,(OCR), is the mechanical or electronic translation of scanned images of handwritten, typewritten or printed text into machine»encoded text

.
> It is widely used to convert books and documents into electronic files, to computerize a record»keeping system in an office, or to publish the text on a website

.
> OCR makes it possible to edit the text, search for a word or phrase, store it more compactly.

Google is facing fresh criticism after admitting that it has not deleted all of the private data, including emails and pass- words, it secretly collected from internet users around the UK as it gathered data for its Street View maps.

The search ﬁrm was ordered in Decem- ber 2010 to delete the private information hoovered up by its Street View cars from open Wi-Fi networks. *
But yesterday Google told the Infor- mation Commissioner’s Ofﬁce “human error” had prevented it from erasing the data, which could include the millions of emails and passwords .
Google admitted in May 2010 its Street View cars had “mistakenly” collected pri-

Almonds
There are a lot ofhealth beneﬁts associated with almonds.
Almonds are very high in vitamin E and protein as well as other nutrients such as magmsium and phosphoms.
Almonds contain anli-cancer properties as well.
\Vhether almonds are best raw or pasteurized is still a source ofhealed debate.

“My dear fellow," said Sherlock Holmes as we sat on either side of the fire in his lodgings at Baker Street, "life is infinitely stranger than anything which the mind of man cnuld invent.
We would not dare to conceive the things which are really mere commonplaces of existence.

If we could ﬂy out of that window hand in hand, hover over this great city, gently remove lhe roofs, and peep in at the queer things which are going on, the strange coincidences. the plannings, the cross—purposes, (he wonderful chains of events, working through generations, and leading to ihe mosi outre’ results, it would make all ﬁction with its conventionaiiiies and foreseen conclusions most stale and unprofitable."
“And yet I am not convinced of it," I answered.
“The cases which come to lighl in the papers are. as a rule. bald enough, and vulgar enough.
We have in our police reports realism pushed to its extreme limits, and yet the result is, it must be confessed, neither fascinating nor mistic."
“A certain selection and discretion musi be used in producing a realistic effect," remarked Holmes.

“This is wanting in the police report, where more stress is laid. perhaps, upon the platitudes of the magistrate than upon ihe details, which to an observer contain the vital essence of the whole matter.
Depend upon it, there is nothing so unnatural as the commonplace."

Tms publication of the Works of Joan Knox, it. is supposed, will extend to Five Volumes.
It was thought advisable to commence the series with his Histmry of the Reformation in Scotland, as the work of greatest importance.
The next, volume will thus contain the Third and Fourth Bookg which continue the History to the year 1564; at which period his historical labours my be considered to tenninebe.
But the Fiﬁh Book, forming a. sequel to the History, and published under his name in 1644, will also be included.

His Letters and Mieoellancuus Writings will be arranged in the mhsequent volumes, as nearly as possible in chronolo- gical order; each portion being introduced by a separate notice, respecting the manuscript or printed copies from which they have been taken.
It may perhaps be expected that a Life of the Author FllOllld have been preﬁxed to this volume.

M‘lez, is however a work so universally known. and of so much historical value, as to supersede any attempt that mighm lie made for a detailed bio-

PREFACE.

IN giving to the public this volume, it has been the design m present the operations of the Bureau of the Nation- al Detective Police during the wax, so fu- us it is proper to make them known to the people, It is not a book of roman- ﬁc adventures, but a narrative of facts in the secret history at the conﬂict, and mainly an exposure of the manifold and gigantic frauds and crimes of both the- openly disloynl and the professed friends of the Repnbﬁc.

Many reports are introduced, some of which are lengthy, and porﬁons of them Are dry, because they are the eﬂicial remrds of the work done, and the veriﬁcation of the statements made, and the highest vindication of the character and importance of the secret service.

Passages occur in them, the propriety of which many readers may question, but their omission would have weakened the strength of the repute, and softened down the enormity of the offenses charged upon certain individuals.

The Whole volume might have besn' made up of chapters very similar to those of the ﬁrst hundred pages

CHAPTER I.

Down the Rabbit-Hole
Alice was beginning to get very tired of sitting by her sister on the bank, and of having nothing to do: once or twice she had peeped into the book her sister was reading, but it had no pictures or conversations in it, 'and what is the use of a book,‘ thought Alice 'without pictures or conversation?

‘
So she was considering in her own mind (as well as she could, for the hot day made her feel very sleepy and stupid), whether the pleasure of making a daisy-chain would be worth the trouble of getting up and picking the daisies, when suddenly a White Rabbit with pink eyes ran close by her.
There was nothing so VERY remarkable in that; nor did Alice think it so VERY much out of the way to hear the Rabbit say to itself, 'Oh dear!
Oh dear!
I shall be Iate!

‘ (when she thought it over afterwards, it occurred to her that she ought to have wondered at this, but at the time it all seemed quite natural); but when the Rabbit actually TOOK A WATCH OUT OF ITS WAISTCOAT—POCKET, and looked at it, and then hurried on, Alice started to her feet, for it flashed across her mind that she had never before seen a rabbit with either a waistcoat-pocket, or a watch to take out of it, and burning with curiosity, she ran across the field after it, and fortunately was just in time to see it pop down a large rabbit-hoIe under the hedge.
In another moment down went Alice after it, never once considering how in the world she was to get out again.

The rabbit-hoIe went straight on like a tunnel for some way, and then dipped suddenly down, so suddenly that Alice had not a moment to think about stopping herself before she found herself falling down a very deep well.

- Automatic insurance documents key information extraction
- Extracting business card information into a contact list
